intro: Teucrium sieberi var. hirtum, commonly known as the hairy germander, is a perennial herb native to regions of Central Asia and the Caucasus. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are usually purple or blue, arranged in dense terminal clusters. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often hairy, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or dry habitats.
